4. Statistics
4.1 Intro
We estimate probability models parameters Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø from data D\mathcal{D}DÔªø. Most methods are optimizations of the form:
Œ∏^=arg‚Äâmin‚Å°Œ∏L(Œ∏)\begin{equation} \hat{\theta}=\argmin_{\theta} \mathcal{L}(\theta) \end{equation}Œ∏^=Œ∏argmin‚ÄãL(Œ∏)‚Äã‚Äã
4.2 Maximum likelihood estimation (MLE)
4.2.1 Definition
Pick the parameter estimation assigning the highest probability to the training data, defined as:
Œ∏^mle‚âúarg‚Äâmax‚Å°Œ∏p(D‚à£Œ∏)\begin{equation} \hat{\theta}_{mle} \triangleq \argmax_{\theta}p(\mathcal{D}|\theta) \end{equation}Œ∏^mle‚Äã‚âúŒ∏argmax‚Äãp(D‚à£Œ∏)‚Äã‚Äã
Wit the i.i.d. assumptions this becomes:
p(D‚à£Œ∏)=‚àèn=1Np(yn‚à£xn,Œ∏)\begin{equation} p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)=\prod^N_{n=1}p(\bold{y}_n|\bold{x}_n,\theta) \end{equation}p(D‚à£Œ∏)=n=1‚àèN‚Äãp(yn‚Äã‚à£xn‚Äã,Œ∏)‚Äã‚Äã
And the Negative Log Likelihood (since most optimization algorithms are designed to minimize cost functions)
NLL(Œ∏)‚âú‚àí‚àën=1Nlog‚Å°p(yn‚à£xn,Œ∏)\begin{equation} NLL(\theta)\triangleq -\sum^N_{n=1}\log p(\bold{y}_n|\bold{x}_n,\theta) \end{equation}NLL(Œ∏)‚âú‚àín=1‚àëN‚Äãlogp(yn‚Äã‚à£xn‚Äã,Œ∏)‚Äã‚Äã
With
Œ∏^mle=arg‚Äâmin‚Å°Œ∏NLL(Œ∏)\hat{\theta}_{mle}= \argmin_{\theta} NLL(\theta)Œ∏^mle‚Äã=Œ∏argmin‚ÄãNLL(Œ∏)
4.2.2 Justification for MLE
MLE can be viewed as a point estimation to the Bayesian posterior p(Œ∏‚à£D)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})p(Œ∏‚à£D)Ôªø
Œ∏^map=arg‚Äâmax‚Å°Œ∏log‚Å°p(Œ∏‚à£D)=arg‚Äâmax‚Å°log‚Å°p(D‚à£Œ∏)+log‚Å°p(Œ∏)\hat{\theta}_{map}= \argmax_{\theta} \log p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=\argmax \log p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)+\log p(\theta)Œ∏^map‚Äã=Œ∏argmax‚Äãlogp(Œ∏‚à£D)=argmaxlogp(D‚à£Œ∏)+logp(Œ∏)
So Œ∏^map=Œ∏^mle\hat{\theta}_{map}=\hat{\theta}_{mle}Œ∏^map‚Äã=Œ∏^mle‚ÄãÔªø if the prior is uniform.
Another way to see the MLE is that the resulting predictive distribution p(y‚à£Œ∏^mle)p(y|\hat{\theta}_{mle})p(y‚à£Œ∏^mle‚Äã)Ôªø is as close as possible to the empirical distribution of the data.
If we defined the empirical distribution by
pD(y)‚âú1N‚àën=1NŒ¥(y‚àíyn)\begin{equation} p_{\mathcal{D}}(\bold{y}) \triangleq \frac{1}{N} \sum_{n=1}^N\delta(y-y_n) \end{equation}pD‚Äã(y)‚âúN1‚Äãn=1‚àëN‚ÄãŒ¥(y‚àíyn‚Äã)‚Äã‚Äã
Minimizing the KL divergence between the empirical p=pDp=p_{\mathcal{D}}p=pD‚ÄãÔªø and an estimated distribution q=p(yn‚à£Œ∏)q=p(y_n|\theta)q=p(yn‚Äã‚à£Œ∏)Ôªø is equivalent to minimizing the NLL and therefore computing the MLE.
DKL(p‚à£‚à£q)‚âú‚àëyp(y)log‚Å°p(y)q(y)=‚àíH(pD)‚àí1N‚àën=1Nlog‚Å°p(yn‚à£Œ∏)=const+NLL(Œ∏)\begin{align} D_{\mathbb{KL}}(p||q) &\triangleq \sum_y p(y) \log \frac{p(y)}{q(y)} \\ &= -\mathbb{H}(p_{\mathcal{D}}) -\frac{1}{N} \sum_{n=1}^N \log p(y_n|\theta) \\ &= \mathrm{const} +\mathrm{NLL}(\theta) \end{align} DKL‚Äã(p‚à£‚à£q)‚Äã‚âúy‚àë‚Äãp(y)logq(y)p(y)‚Äã=‚àíH(pD‚Äã)‚àíN1‚Äãn=1‚àëN‚Äãlogp(yn‚Äã‚à£Œ∏)=const+NLL(Œ∏)‚Äã‚Äã
The same logic applies for supervised settings, with:
pD(x,y)=pD(y‚à£x)pD(x)=1N‚àën=1NŒ¥(x‚àíxn)Œ¥(y‚àíyn)p_{D}(x,y)=p_{\mathcal{D}}(y|x) p_{\mathcal{D}}(x)=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{n=1}^N \delta(x-x_n)\delta(y-y_n)pD‚Äã(x,y)=pD‚Äã(y‚à£x)pD‚Äã(x)=N1‚Äãn=1‚àëN‚ÄãŒ¥(x‚àíxn‚Äã)Œ¥(y‚àíyn‚Äã)
4.2.3 MLE for the Bernoulli distribution
Let Œ∏=p(Y=1)\theta =p(Y=1)Œ∏=p(Y=1)Ôªø be the probability of heads in a coin toss.
NLL(Œ∏)=‚àílog‚Å°‚àèn=1Np(yn‚à£Œ∏)=‚àílog‚Å°‚àèn=1NŒ∏I(yn=1)(1‚àíŒ∏)I(yn=0)=‚àí[N1log‚Å°Œ∏+N0log‚Å°(1‚àíŒ∏)]\begin{align} \mathrm{NLL}(\theta)&=-\log \prod^N_{n=1}p(y_n|\theta) \\ &=-\log \prod^N_{n=1}\theta^{\mathbb{I}(y_n=1)}(1-\theta)^{\mathbb{I}(y_n=0)} \\ &= -[N_1 \log\theta+N_0 \log(1-\theta)] \end{align}NLL(Œ∏)‚Äã=‚àílogn=1‚àèN‚Äãp(yn‚Äã‚à£Œ∏)=‚àílogn=1‚àèN‚ÄãŒ∏I(yn‚Äã=1)(1‚àíŒ∏)I(yn‚Äã=0)=‚àí[N1‚ÄãlogŒ∏+N0‚Äãlog(1‚àíŒ∏)]‚Äã‚Äã
The MLE can be found by:
ddŒ∏NLL(Œ∏)=‚àíN1Œ∏+N01‚àíŒ∏‚áíŒ∏^mle=N1N\frac{d}{d\theta} \mathrm{NLL}(\theta)=- \frac{N_1}{\theta}+\frac{N_0}{1-\theta} \Rightarrow \hat{\theta}_{mle}=\frac{N_1}{N}dŒ∏d‚ÄãNLL(Œ∏)=‚àíŒ∏N1‚Äã‚Äã+1‚àíŒ∏N0‚Äã‚Äã‚áíŒ∏^mle‚Äã=NN1‚Äã‚Äã
4.2.4 MLE for the categorical distribution
Let Yn‚àºCat(Œ∏)Y_n \sim \mathrm{Cat}(\theta)Yn‚Äã‚àºCat(Œ∏)Ôªø.
NLL(Œ∏)=‚àí‚àëkNklog‚Å°Œ∏k\mathrm{NLL}(\theta)=-\sum_k N_k \log \theta_kNLL(Œ∏)=‚àík‚àë‚ÄãNk‚ÄãlogŒ∏k‚Äã
To compute the MLE, we have to minimize the NLL subject the constraint ‚àëk=1KŒ∏k=1\sum^K_{k=1}\theta_k=1‚àëk=1K‚ÄãŒ∏k‚Äã=1Ôªø using the following Lagrangian:
L(Œ∏,Œª)‚âú‚àí‚àëkNklog‚Å°Œ∏k‚àíŒª(1‚àí‚àëkŒ∏k)\mathcal{L}(\theta,\lambda) \triangleq -\sum_kN_k \log \theta_k-\lambda \Big(1-\sum_k \theta_k\Big)L(Œ∏,Œª)‚âú‚àík‚àë‚ÄãNk‚ÄãlogŒ∏k‚Äã‚àíŒª(1‚àík‚àë‚ÄãŒ∏k‚Äã)
We get the MLE by taking the derivative of L\mathcal{L}LÔªø for Œª\lambdaŒªÔªø and Œ∏k\theta_kŒ∏k‚ÄãÔªø
Œ∏^k=NkŒª=NkN\hat{\theta}_k=\frac{N_k}{\lambda}=\frac{N_k}{N}Œ∏^k‚Äã=ŒªNk‚Äã‚Äã=NNk‚Äã‚Äã
4.2.5 MLE for the univariate Gaussian
Suppose Y‚àºN(Œº,œÉ2)Y \sim N(\mu,\sigma^2)Y‚àºN(Œº,œÉ2)Ôªø. We estimate here again the parameters using the MLE:
NLL(Œº,œÉ2)=‚àí‚àën=1Nlog‚Å°[(12œÄœÉ2)12exp‚Å°(‚àí(yn‚àíŒº)22œÉ2)]=12œÉ2‚àën=1N(yn‚àíŒº)2+N2log‚Å°(2œÄœÉ2)\begin{align} \mathrm{NLL}(\mu,\sigma^2) &=-\sum_{n=1}^N \log \Big[\big(\frac{1}{2\pi\sigma^2}\big)^{\frac{1}{2}} \exp\big(-\frac{(y_n-\mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}\big)\Big] \\ &= \frac{1}{2\sigma^2}\sum_{n=1}^N(y_n-\mu)^2 + \frac{N}{2}\log (2\pi\sigma^2) \end{align}NLL(Œº,œÉ2)‚Äã=‚àín=1‚àëN‚Äãlog[(2œÄœÉ21‚Äã)21‚Äãexp(‚àí2œÉ2(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº)2‚Äã)]=2œÉ21‚Äãn=1‚àëN‚Äã(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº)2+2N‚Äãlog(2œÄœÉ2)‚Äã‚Äã
We find the stationary point by ‚àÇ‚àÇŒºNLL(Œº,œÉ2)=0\frac{\partial}{\partial \mu}\mathrm{NLL}(\mu,\sigma^2)=0‚àÇŒº‚àÇ‚ÄãNLL(Œº,œÉ2)=0Ôªø and ‚àÇ‚àÇœÉ2NLL(Œº,œÉ2)=0\frac{\partial}{\partial \sigma^2}\mathrm{NLL}(\mu,\sigma^2)=0‚àÇœÉ2‚àÇ‚ÄãNLL(Œº,œÉ2)=0Ôªø
Œº^mle=1N‚àën=1Nyn=yÀâœÉ^mle2=1N‚àën=1N(yn‚àíŒº^mle)2=s2‚àíyÀâ2s2‚âú1N‚àën=1Nyn2\begin{align} \hat{\mu}_{mle} &=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N y_n=\bar{y} \\ \hat{\sigma}^2_{mle} &= \frac{1}{N}\sum^N_{n=1}(y_n-\hat{\mu}_{mle})^2=s^2- \bar{y}^2 \\ s^2& \triangleq \frac{1}{N}\sum^N_{n=1}y_n^2 \end{align} Œº^‚Äãmle‚ÄãœÉ^mle2‚Äãs2‚Äã=N1‚Äãn=1‚àëN‚Äãyn‚Äã=yÀâ‚Äã=N1‚Äãn=1‚àëN‚Äã(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº^‚Äãmle‚Äã)2=s2‚àíyÀâ‚Äã2‚âúN1‚Äãn=1‚àëN‚Äãyn2‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã
yÀâ\bar{y}yÀâ‚ÄãÔªø and s2s^2s2Ôªø are the sufficient statistics of the data, since they are sufficient to compute the MLE.
The unbiased estimator for variance (not the MLE) is:
œÉ^unb2=1N‚àí1‚àën=1N(yn‚àíŒº^mle)2\hat{\sigma}^2_{unb}=\frac{1}{N-1} \sum^N_{n=1}(y_n-\hat{\mu}_{mle})^2œÉ^unb2‚Äã=N‚àí11‚Äãn=1‚àëN‚Äã(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº^‚Äãmle‚Äã)2
4.2.6 MLE for MVN
LL(Œº,Œ£)=log‚Å°p(D‚à£Œº,Œ£)=‚àí12‚àën=1N(yn‚àíŒº)‚ä§Œõ(yn‚àíŒº)+N2log‚Å°‚à£Œõ‚à£\mathrm{LL}(\mu,\Sigma)=\log p(\mathcal{D}|\mu,\Sigma)=-\frac{1}{2}\sum_{n=1}^N(y_n-\mu)^\top\Lambda(y_n-\mu)+\frac{N}{2} \log|\Lambda|LL(Œº,Œ£)=logp(D‚à£Œº,Œ£)=‚àí21‚Äãn=1‚àëN‚Äã(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº)‚ä§Œõ(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº)+2N‚Äãlog‚à£Œõ‚à£
with Œõ=Œ£‚àí1\Lambda=\Sigma^{-1}Œõ=Œ£‚àí1Ôªø the precision matrix.
Using zn=yn‚àíŒºz_n=y_n-\muzn‚Äã=yn‚Äã‚àíŒºÔªø:
‚àÇ‚àÇŒº(yn‚àíŒº)‚ä§Œ£‚àí1(yn‚àíŒº)=‚àÇ‚àÇznzn‚ä§Œ£‚àí1zn‚àÇzn‚àÇŒº=‚àí(Œ£‚àí1+Œ£‚àíT)zn\frac{\partial}{\partial \mu}(y_n-\mu)^\top \Sigma^{-1}(y_n-\mu)=\frac{\partial}{\partial z_n}z_n^\top\Sigma^{-1}z_n\frac{\partial z_n}{\partial \mu}=-(\Sigma^{-1}+\Sigma^{-T})z_n‚àÇŒº‚àÇ‚Äã(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº)‚ä§Œ£‚àí1(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº)=‚àÇzn‚Äã‚àÇ‚Äãzn‚ä§‚ÄãŒ£‚àí1zn‚Äã‚àÇŒº‚àÇzn‚Äã‚Äã=‚àí(Œ£‚àí1+Œ£‚àíT)zn‚Äã
Hence
‚àÇ‚àÇŒºLL(Œº,Œ£)=‚àí12‚àë‚àí2Œ£‚àí1(yn‚àíŒº)=0‚áíŒº^=yÀâ\frac{\partial}{\partial \mu}\mathrm{LL}(\mu,\Sigma)=-\frac{1}{2}\sum -2\Sigma^{-1}(y_n-\mu)=0 \\\Rightarrow \hat{\mu}=\bar{y}‚àÇŒº‚àÇ‚ÄãLL(Œº,Œ£)=‚àí21‚Äã‚àë‚àí2Œ£‚àí1(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº)=0‚áíŒº^‚Äã=yÀâ‚Äã
So the MLE of Œº\muŒºÔªø is just the empirical mean.
Using the trace trick:
LL(Œº^,Œõ)=‚àí12‚àëntr[(yn‚àíŒº)(yn‚àíŒº)‚ä§Œõ]+N2log‚Å°‚à£Œõ‚à£=‚àí12tr[SyÀâŒõ]+N2log‚Å°‚à£Œõ‚à£\begin{align} \mathrm{LL}(\hat{\mu},\Lambda)&=-\frac{1}{2} \sum_ntr[(y_n-\mu)(y_n-\mu)^\top \Lambda]+\frac{N}{2}\log |\Lambda| \\ &= -\frac{1}{2} tr[S_{\bar{y}} \Lambda]+\frac{N}{2}\log |\Lambda| \end{align}LL(Œº^‚Äã,Œõ)‚Äã=‚àí21‚Äãn‚àë‚Äãtr[(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº)(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº)‚ä§Œõ]+2N‚Äãlog‚à£Œõ‚à£=‚àí21‚Äãtr[SyÀâ‚Äã‚ÄãŒõ]+2N‚Äãlog‚à£Œõ‚à£‚Äã‚Äã
With SyÀâ=‚àën(yn‚àíyÀâ)(yn‚àíyÀâ)‚ä§S_{\bar{y}}=\sum_n(y_n-\bar{y})(y_n-\bar{y})^\topSyÀâ‚Äã‚Äã=‚àën‚Äã(yn‚Äã‚àíyÀâ‚Äã)(yn‚Äã‚àíyÀâ‚Äã)‚ä§Ôªø the scatter matrix centered on yÀâ\bar{y}yÀâ‚ÄãÔªø
Resolving the derivative for Œõ\LambdaŒõÔªø gives Œõ^‚àí1=Œ£=1NSyÀâ\hat{\Lambda}^{-1}=\Sigma=\frac{1}{N} S_{\bar{y}}Œõ^‚àí1=Œ£=N1‚ÄãSyÀâ‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø
4.2.7 MLE for linear regression
Let suppose the model corresponds to p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)=N(y‚à£w‚ä§x,œÉ2)p(y|x,\theta)=\mathcal{N}(y|w^\top x,\sigma^2)p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)=N(y‚à£w‚ä§x,œÉ2)Ôªø. If we fix œÉ2\sigma^2œÉ2Ôªø to focus on wwwÔªø:
LL(w)=‚àí‚àën=1Nlog‚Å°[(12œÄœÉ2)1/2exp‚Å°(‚àí12œÉ2(yn‚àíw‚ä§xn)2)]\mathrm{LL}(w)=-\sum_{n=1}^N \log \Bigg[ \Big(\frac{1}{2\pi\sigma^2}\Big)^{1/2} \exp\Big(-\frac{1}{2\sigma^2}(y_n-w^\top x_n)^2\Big) \Bigg]LL(w)=‚àín=1‚àëN‚Äãlog[(2œÄœÉ21‚Äã)1/2exp(‚àí2œÉ21‚Äã(yn‚Äã‚àíw‚ä§xn‚Äã)2)]
Dropping the irrelevant additive constants:
RSS(w)‚âú‚àën=1N(yn‚àíw‚ä§xn)2=‚àën=1Nrn2\mathrm{RSS}(w) \triangleq \sum_{n=1}^N (y_n-w^\top x_n)^2=\sum^N_{n=1}r_n^2RSS(w)‚âún=1‚àëN‚Äã(yn‚Äã‚àíw‚ä§xn‚Äã)2=n=1‚àëN‚Äãrn2‚Äã
Note that MSE=1NRSS\mathrm{MSE}=\frac{1}{N}\mathrm{RSS}MSE=N1‚ÄãRSSÔªø and RMSE=MSE\mathrm{RMSE}=\sqrt{MSE}RMSE=MSE‚ÄãÔªø
Writing the RSS\mathrm{RSS}RSSÔªø in matrix notation:
RSS(w)=‚à£‚à£Xw‚ä§‚àíy‚à£‚à£22\mathrm{RSS}(w)=||\bold{X}w^\top-\bold{y}||^2_2RSS(w)=‚à£‚à£Xw‚ä§‚àíy‚à£‚à£22‚Äã
And the equation of OLS is:
w^mle‚âúarg‚Äâmin‚Å°wRSS(w)=(X‚ä§X)‚àí1X‚ä§y\hat{w}_{mle} \triangleq \argmin_w \mathrm{RSS}(w) = \bold{(X^\top X)^{-1}X^\top y}w^mle‚Äã‚âúwargmin‚ÄãRSS(w)=(X‚ä§X)‚àí1X‚ä§y
4.3 Empirical risk minimization (ERM)
We can generalize the MLE by replacing the loss loss term with any other loss to get:
L(Œ∏)=1N‚àën=1Nl(yn,xn,Œ∏)\mathcal{L}(\theta)=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N\mathcal{l}(y_n,x_n,\theta)L(Œ∏)=N1‚Äãn=1‚àëN‚Äãl(yn‚Äã,xn‚Äã,Œ∏)
4.3.1 Misclassification rate
Let y~‚àà{‚àí1,+1}\tilde{y} \in \{-1,+1\}y~‚Äã‚àà{‚àí1,+1}Ôªø our true label and y^‚àà{‚àí1,+1}=f(x,Œ∏)\hat{y}\in \{-1,+1\}=f(x,\theta)y^‚Äã‚àà{‚àí1,+1}=f(x,Œ∏)Ôªø our prediction
We can define the loss as the misclassification rate l01(y~,y^)=I(y~‚â†y^)=I(y~y^<0)l_{01}(\tilde{y},\hat{y})=\mathbb{I}(\tilde{y} \neq \hat{y})=\mathbb{I}(\tilde{y} \hat{y}<0)l01‚Äã(y~‚Äã,y^‚Äã)=I(y~‚ÄãÓÄ†=y^‚Äã)=I(y~‚Äãy^‚Äã<0)Ôªø
4.3.2 Surrogate loss
Unfortunately, the 0-1 loss is non smooth, making it NP-hard to optimize. Here we use a surrogate loss function, a maximally tight convex upper bound, easy to minimize.
For exemple, let
p(y~‚à£x,Œ∏)=œÉ(y~Œ∑)=11+e‚àíy~Œ∑p(\tilde{y}|x,\theta) = \sigma(\tilde{y}\eta )=\frac{1}{1+e^{-\tilde{y}\eta}}p(y~‚Äã‚à£x,Œ∏)=œÉ(y~‚ÄãŒ∑)=1+e‚àíy~‚ÄãŒ∑1‚Äã
where Œ∑=f(x,Œ∏)\eta=f(x,\theta)Œ∑=f(x,Œ∏)Ôªø is the logs odds
The log loss is
l(y~,Œ∑)=log‚Å°(1+e‚àíy~Œ∑)l(\tilde{y},\eta)=\log(1+e^{-\tilde{y}\eta})l(y~‚Äã,Œ∑)=log(1+e‚àíy~‚ÄãŒ∑)
This is a smooth upper bound to the 0-1 loss where y~Œ∑\tilde{y}\etay~‚ÄãŒ∑Ôªø is the margin (it defines a ‚Äúmargin of safety‚Äù away from the threshold at 0)
4.4 Other estimation methods
4.4.1 The methods of moment (MOM)
MOM is a simpler approach than computing MLE. Solve KKKÔªø number of equations (KKKÔªø is the number of parameters).
The theoretical moments are given by Œºk=E[Yk]\mu_k=\mathbb{E}[Y^k]Œºk‚Äã=E[Yk]Ôªø
The empirical moments are given by Œº^k=1N‚àënynk\hat{\mu}_k=\frac{1}{N}\sum_ny_n^kŒº^‚Äãk‚Äã=N1‚Äã‚àën‚Äãynk‚ÄãÔªø
We solve Œºk=Œº^k\mu_k=\hat{\mu}_kŒºk‚Äã=Œº^‚Äãk‚ÄãÔªø for every k.
Example with the univariate Gaussian:
Œº1=Œº=yÀâ\mu_1=\mu=\bar{y}Œº1‚Äã=Œº=yÀâ‚ÄãÔªø
Œº2=œÉ2+Œº2=s2\mu_2=\sigma^2+\mu^2=s^2Œº2‚Äã=œÉ2+Œº2=s2Ôªø (since œÉ2=s2‚àíŒº2\sigma^2=s^2-\mu^2œÉ2=s2‚àíŒº2Ôªø)
so:
Œº^=yÀâ\hat{\mu}=\bar{y}Œº^‚Äã=yÀâ‚ÄãÔªø
œÉ^2=s2‚àíyÀâ2\hat{\sigma}^2=s^2-\bar{y}^2œÉ^2=s2‚àíyÀâ‚Äã2Ôªø
So in this case, this is similar to MLE.
Example with the uniform distribution:
p(y‚à£Œ∏)=1Œ∏2‚àíŒ∏1I(Œ∏1‚â§y‚â§Œ∏2)p(y|\theta)=\frac{1}{\theta_2-\theta_1} \mathbb{I}(\theta_1\leq y\leq\theta_2)p(y‚à£Œ∏)=Œ∏2‚Äã‚àíŒ∏1‚Äã1‚ÄãI(Œ∏1‚Äã‚â§y‚â§Œ∏2‚Äã)
Œº1=E[Y]=Œ∏1+Œ∏22\mu_1=\mathbb{E}[Y]=\frac{\theta_1+\theta_2}{2}Œº1‚Äã=E[Y]=2Œ∏1‚Äã+Œ∏2‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø
Œº2=E[Y2]=Œ∏12+Œ∏2Œ∏1+Œ∏123\mu_2=\mathbb{E}[Y^2]=\frac{\theta_1^2+\theta_2\theta_1+\theta_1^2}{3}Œº2‚Äã=E[Y2]=3Œ∏12‚Äã+Œ∏2‚ÄãŒ∏1‚Äã+Œ∏12‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø
Inverting these equations to get Œ∏1\theta_1Œ∏1‚ÄãÔªø and Œ∏2\theta_2Œ∏2‚ÄãÔªø, we see that these estimators sometimes give incorrect results.
To compute the MLE, we sort the data values. The likelihood is:
p(D‚à£Œ∏1,Œ∏1)=(1Œ∏2‚àíŒ∏1)NI(Œ∏1‚â§y1)I(yN‚â§Œ∏2)p(\mathcal{D}|\theta_1, \theta_1)=(\frac{1}{\theta_2-\theta_1})^N \mathbb{I}(\theta_1\leq y_1)\mathbb{I}(y_N\leq\theta_2)p(D‚à£Œ∏1‚Äã,Œ∏1‚Äã)=(Œ∏2‚Äã‚àíŒ∏1‚Äã1‚Äã)NI(Œ∏1‚Äã‚â§y1‚Äã)I(yN‚Äã‚â§Œ∏2‚Äã)
Then, if we set Œ∏=Œ∏2‚àíŒ∏1\theta=\theta_2-\theta_1Œ∏=Œ∏2‚Äã‚àíŒ∏1‚ÄãÔªø
ddŒ∏NLL(Œ∏)=NŒ∏2‚àíŒ∏1\frac{d}{d\theta} \mathrm{NLL}(\theta)=\frac{N}{\theta_2-\theta_1}dŒ∏d‚ÄãNLL(Œ∏)=Œ∏2‚Äã‚àíŒ∏1‚ÄãN‚Äã
This is minimized by Œ∏^1=y1\hat{\theta}_1=y_1Œ∏^1‚Äã=y1‚ÄãÔªø and Œ∏^2=yN\hat{\theta}_2=y_NŒ∏^2‚Äã=yN‚ÄãÔªø, as one would expect.
4.4.2 Online (recursive) estimation
When data arrives sequentially we perform online learning.
Let Œ∏^t‚àí1\hat{\theta}_{t-1}Œ∏^t‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø our estimate (e.g. MLE) given D1:t‚àí1\mathcal{D}_{1:t-1}D1:t‚àí1‚ÄãÔªø. To ensure our algorithms takes a constant time per update, our solution is in the form:
Œ∏^t=f(Œ∏^t‚àí1,ft)\hat{\theta}_t=f(\hat{\theta}_{t-1},f_t)Œ∏^t‚Äã=f(Œ∏^t‚àí1‚Äã,ft‚Äã)
Example for the mean of Gaussian:
Œº^t=‚àën=1tyn=1t((t‚àí1)Œº^t‚àí1+yt)=Œº^t‚àí1+1t(yt‚àíŒº^t‚àí1)\hat{\mu}_t=\sum_{n=1}^t y_n=\frac{1}{t}\Big((t-1)\hat{\mu}_{t-1}+y_t\Big)=\hat{\mu}_{t-1}+\frac{1}{t}(y_t-\hat{\mu}_{t-1})Œº^‚Äãt‚Äã=n=1‚àët‚Äãyn‚Äã=t1‚Äã((t‚àí1)Œº^‚Äãt‚àí1‚Äã+yt‚Äã)=Œº^‚Äãt‚àí1‚Äã+t1‚Äã(yt‚Äã‚àíŒº^‚Äãt‚àí1‚Äã)
This is a moving average, the size of the correction diminish over time. However if the distribution is changing, we might want to give more weight to recent data points.
This is solved by exponentially-weighted moving average (EWMA)
Œº^t=Œ≤Œº^t‚Äî1+(1‚àíŒ≤)yt\hat{\mu}_t=\beta \hat{\mu}_{t‚Äî1}+(1-\beta)y_tŒº^‚Äãt‚Äã=Œ≤Œº^‚Äãt‚Äî1‚Äã+(1‚àíŒ≤)yt‚Äã
with 0<Œ≤<10<\beta<10<Œ≤<1Ôªø
The contribution of a data point in k steps is Œ≤k(1‚àíŒ≤)\beta^k(1-\beta)Œ≤k(1‚àíŒ≤)Ôªø.
Since the initial estimate starts from Œº^0=0\hat{\mu}_0=0Œº^‚Äã0‚Äã=0Ôªø there is an initial bias, corrected by scaling as
Œº~t=Œº^t1‚àíŒ≤t\tilde{\mu}_t=\frac{\hat{\mu}_t}{1-\beta^t}Œº~‚Äãt‚Äã=1‚àíŒ≤tŒº^‚Äãt‚Äã‚Äã
4.5 Regularization
The main issue with MLE and ERM is that they pick parameters minimizing the loss on the training set, which can result in overfitting.
With enough parameters, a model can match any empirical distribution. However, in most cases the empirical distribution is not the same as the true distribution. Regularization add a penalty term to the NLL.
L(Œ∏,Œª)=1N‚àëi=1Nl(yn,Œ∏,xn)+ŒªC(Œ∏)=‚àí1N‚àëi=1Nlog‚Å°p(yn‚à£xn,Œ∏)‚àíŒªlog‚Å°p(Œ∏)\begin{align} \mathcal{L}(\theta,\lambda)&=\frac{1}{N}\sum^N_{i=1}l(y_n,\theta,x_n)+\lambda C(\theta) \\ &=-\frac{1}{N}\sum^N_{i=1} \log p(y_n|x_n,\theta) -\lambda \log p(\theta) \end{align} L(Œ∏,Œª)‚Äã=N1‚Äãi=1‚àëN‚Äãl(yn‚Äã,Œ∏,xn‚Äã)+ŒªC(Œ∏)=‚àíN1‚Äãi=1‚àëN‚Äãlogp(yn‚Äã‚à£xn‚Äã,Œ∏)‚àíŒªlogp(Œ∏)‚Äã‚Äã
by taking the log loss and the log prior for penalty term.
This is equivalent to minimizing the MAP:
Œ∏^map=arg‚Äâmax‚Å°Œ∏log‚Å°p(Œ∏‚à£D)=arg‚Äâmax‚Å°Œ∏[log‚Å°p(D‚à£Œ∏)+log‚Å°p(Œ∏)‚àíconst]\hat{\theta}_{map}=\argmax_{\theta} \log p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=\argmax_{\theta} [\log p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)+\log p(\theta) -\mathrm{const}]Œ∏^map‚Äã=Œ∏argmax‚Äãlogp(Œ∏‚à£D)=Œ∏argmax‚Äã[logp(D‚à£Œ∏)+logp(Œ∏)‚àíconst]
4.5.1 MAP for Bernoulli distribution
If we observe just one head, Œ∏mle=1\theta_{mle}=1Œ∏mle‚Äã=1Ôªø. We add a penalty to Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø to discourage extreme values.
With p(Œ∏)‚àºBeta(a,b)p(\theta)\sim Beta(a,b)p(Œ∏)‚àºBeta(a,b)Ôªø, and a,b>1a,b>1a,b>1Ôªø, we encourage values of Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø near to the mean a/(a+b){a}/(a+b)a/(a+b)Ôªø
LL(Œ∏)=log‚Å°p(D‚à£Œ∏)+log‚Å°p(Œ∏)=N0log‚Å°Œ∏+N1log‚Å°(1‚àíŒ∏)+(a‚àí1)log‚Å°Œ∏+(b‚àí1)log‚Å°(1‚àíŒ∏)\begin{align} \mathrm{LL}(\theta)&=\log p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)+\log p(\theta) \\ &= N_0 \log\theta+ N_1 \log(1 - \theta) + (a-1)\log \theta + (b-1)\log (1-\theta) \end{align}LL(Œ∏)‚Äã=logp(D‚à£Œ∏)+logp(Œ∏)=N0‚ÄãlogŒ∏+N1‚Äãlog(1‚àíŒ∏)+(a‚àí1)logŒ∏+(b‚àí1)log(1‚àíŒ∏)‚Äã‚Äã
With the same method as the MLE, we find:
Œ∏^map=N1+a‚àí1N+a+b‚àí2=N1+1N+2\hat{\theta}_{map}=\frac{N_1+a-1}{N+a+b-2}=\frac{N_1+1}{N+2}Œ∏^map‚Äã=N+a+b‚àí2N1‚Äã+a‚àí1‚Äã=N+2N1‚Äã+1‚Äã
By setting a=2,b=2a=2, b=2a=2,b=2Ôªø, we resolve the zero-count problem.
Regularization combines empirical data and prior knowledge.
4.5.2 MAP for MVN
We showed that the MLE for covariance of a MVN is Œ£^=1NSyÀâ\hat{\Sigma}=\frac{1}{N}S_{\bar{y}}Œ£^=N1‚ÄãSyÀâ‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø. In high dimensions, the scatter matrix can easily become singular. One solution is to perform MAP estimation.
A convenient prior to use for Œ£\SigmaŒ£Ôªø is the Wishart distribution (generalization of the Gamma distribution). The resulting MAP is:
Œ£^map=SÀò+SyÀâNÀò+N=NÀòNÀò+NSÀòNÀò+NNÀò+NSyÀâN=ŒªŒ£0+(1‚àíŒª)Œ£^mle\hat{\Sigma}_{map}=\frac{\breve{S}+S_{\bar{y}}}{\breve{N}+N}=\frac{\breve{N}}{\breve{N}+N}\frac{\breve{S}}{\breve{N}}+\frac{N}{\breve{N}+N}\frac{S_{\bar{y}}}{N}=\lambda \Sigma_0+(1-\lambda)\hat{\Sigma}_{mle}Œ£^map‚Äã=NÀò+NSÀò+SyÀâ‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã=NÀò+NNÀò‚ÄãNÀòSÀò‚Äã+NÀò+NN‚ÄãNSyÀâ‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã=ŒªŒ£0‚Äã+(1‚àíŒª)Œ£^mle‚Äã
where Œª\lambdaŒªÔªø controls the amount of regularization.
If we set SÀò=Ndiag(Œ£^mle)\breve{S}=N \mathrm{diag}(\hat{\Sigma}_{mle})SÀò=Ndiag(Œ£^mle‚Äã)Ôªø:
Œ£^map(i,j)={Œ£^mleif‚Äâi=j(1‚àíŒª)Œ£^mleo.w.\hat{\Sigma}_{map}(i,j)=\begin{cases} \hat{\Sigma}_{mle}&\mathrm{if}\,i=j \\ (1-\lambda)\hat{\Sigma}_{mle} & o.w. \end{cases}Œ£^map‚Äã(i,j)={Œ£^mle‚Äã(1‚àíŒª)Œ£^mle‚Äã‚Äãifi=jo.w.‚Äã
Off-diagonal elements are shrunk toward 0. Œª\lambdaŒªÔªø can be chosen via cross-validation of via close form (implemented in scikit-learn LedoitWolf).
The benefits of the MAP is to better behaved than MLE, with eigenvalues of the estimate closer to that of the true covariance matrix (the eigenvectors however are unaffected).
4.5.3 Weight decay
We saw that reducing the degree of the polynomial help the regression task. A more general solution is to add regularization to the regression coefficients.
w^map=arg‚Äâmin‚Å°wNLL(w)+Œª‚à£‚à£w‚à£‚à£22\hat{w}_{map}=\argmin_w \mathrm{NLL}(w)+\lambda ||w||_2^2w^map‚Äã=wargmin‚ÄãNLL(w)+Œª‚à£‚à£w‚à£‚à£22‚Äã
where a higher Œª\lambdaŒªÔªø means more pressure toward low coefficients and thus less flexibility for the model. This is ridge regression.
4.5.4 Picking Œª\lambdaŒªÔªø by cross validation
We split the training data into K folds and iteratively fit on all fold except one, used for validation.
We have
RŒª(Œ∏,D)=1‚à£D‚à£‚àë(x,y)‚ààD‚Ñì(y,f(x,Œ∏))+ŒªC(Œ∏)R_\lambda(\theta,\mathcal{D})=\frac{1}{|D|}\sum_{(x,y) \in \mathcal{D}} \ell(y,f(x,\theta))+\lambda C(\theta)RŒª‚Äã(Œ∏,D)=‚à£D‚à£1‚Äã(x,y)‚ààD‚àë‚Äã‚Ñì(y,f(x,Œ∏))+ŒªC(Œ∏)
So
Œª^=arg‚Äâmin‚Å°ŒªRŒªcv=arg‚Äâmin‚Å°Œª1K‚àëk=1KR0(Œ∏^Œª(D‚àík),Dk)\hat{\lambda} =\argmin_\lambda R^{cv}_\lambda =\argmin_\lambda\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^K R_0(\hat{\theta}_{\lambda}(\mathcal{D}_{-k}),\mathcal{D}_k)Œª^=Œªargmin‚ÄãRŒªcv‚Äã=Œªargmin‚ÄãK1‚Äãk=1‚àëK‚ÄãR0‚Äã(Œ∏^Œª‚Äã(D‚àík‚Äã),Dk‚Äã)
Finally
Œ∏^=arg‚Äâmin‚Å°Œ∏RŒª^(Œ∏,D)\hat{\theta}=\argmin_{\theta}R_{\hat{\lambda}}(\theta,\mathcal{D})Œ∏^=Œ∏argmin‚ÄãRŒª^‚Äã(Œ∏,D)
The standard error of our estimate is:
se=œÉ^n\mathrm{se}=\frac{\hat{\sigma}}{\sqrt{n}}se=n‚ÄãœÉ^‚Äã
where œÉ^=Var[‚Ñì(y,f(x,Œ∏^)]\hat{\sigma}=\mathrm{Var}[\ell(y,f(x,\hat{\theta})]œÉ^=Var[‚Ñì(y,f(x,Œ∏^)]Ôªø
4.5.7 Using more data
When a model is too simplistic, it fails to improve as the data grow. A overly complex model will end up converging toward the right solution if enough data is provided.
4.6 Bayesian statistics
Inference is modeling uncertainty about parameters using a probability distribution (instead of a point estimate). In Bayesian statistics we use the posterior distribution.
p(Œ∏‚à£D)=p(D‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏)p(D)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=\frac{p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(\theta)}{p(\mathcal{D})}p(Œ∏‚à£D)=p(D)p(D‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏)‚Äã
Once we have computed the posterior over Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø, we compute the posterior predictive distribution by marginalizing out Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø. In the supervised setting:
p(y‚à£x,D)=‚à´p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£D)dŒ∏p(y|x,\mathcal{D})=\int p(y|x,\theta)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})d\thetap(y‚à£x,D)=‚à´p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£D)dŒ∏
This is Bayes model averaging (BMA), since we use an infinite amount set of models, weighted by how likely their parameters are.
4.6.1 Conjugate prior
A prior p(Œ∏)‚ààFp(\theta)\in\mathcal{F}p(Œ∏)‚ààFÔªø is conjugate for a likelihood function p(D‚à£Œ∏)p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(D‚à£Œ∏)Ôªø if the posterior p(Œ∏‚à£D)‚ààFp(\theta|\mathcal{D})\in\mathcal{F}p(Œ∏‚à£D)‚ààFÔªø. The family F\mathcal{F}FÔªø is closed under bayesian updating.
For simplicity, we consider a model without covariates.
4.6.2 Beta-binomial model
We toss a coin NNNÔªø times to estimate the head probability Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø. We want to compute p(Œ∏‚à£D)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})p(Œ∏‚à£D)Ôªø.
Under the iid hypothesis:
p(D‚à£Œ∏)=Œ∏N1(1‚àíŒ∏)N0p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)=\theta^{N_1}(1-\theta)^{N_0}p(D‚à£Œ∏)=Œ∏N1‚Äã(1‚àíŒ∏)N0‚Äã
Instead of observing a sequence of coin toss, we can count the number of heads using a binomial likelihood
p(D‚à£Œ∏)=Bin(y‚à£N,Œ∏)=(Ny)Œ∏y(1‚àíŒ∏)N‚àíyp(\mathcal{D}|\theta)=\mathrm{Bin}(y|N,\theta)=\binom{N}{y}\theta^{y}(1-\theta)^{N-y}p(D‚à£Œ∏)=Bin(y‚à£N,Œ∏)=(yN‚Äã)Œ∏y(1‚àíŒ∏)N‚àíy
Since these likelihood are proportional, we will use the same inference about Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø for both models.
The Beta distribution is the conjugate prior to Bernoulli or Binomial likelihood.
p(Œ∏)=Beta(Œ∏‚à£a,b)=Œ∏a‚àí1(1‚àíŒ∏)b‚àí1p(\theta)=\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|a,b)=\theta^{a-1}(1-\theta)^{b-1}p(Œ∏)=Beta(Œ∏‚à£a,b)=Œ∏a‚àí1(1‚àíŒ∏)b‚àí1
We obtained the posterior
p(Œ∏‚à£D)=Œ∏a‚àí1+N1(1‚àíŒ∏)b‚àí1+N0=Beta(Œ∏‚à£a+N1,b+N0)=Beta(Œ∏‚à£aÀò,bÀò)\begin{align} p(\theta|\mathcal{D})&=\theta^{a-1+N_1}(1-\theta)^{b-1+N_0} \\ &=\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|a+N_1,b+N_0) \\ &=\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|\breve{a},\breve{b}) \end{align} p(Œ∏‚à£D)‚Äã=Œ∏a‚àí1+N1‚Äã(1‚àíŒ∏)b‚àí1+N0‚Äã=Beta(Œ∏‚à£a+N1‚Äã,b+N0‚Äã)=Beta(Œ∏‚à£aÀò,bÀò)‚Äã‚Äã
Here the hyper-parameters of the prior a,ba,ba,bÔªø play an similar role to the sufficient statistics N1,N0N_1,N_0N1‚Äã,N0‚ÄãÔªø. We call a,ba,ba,bÔªø pseudo counts and N1,N0N_1,N_0N1‚Äã,N0‚ÄãÔªø observed counts.
If we set a=b=2a=b=2a=b=2Ôªø, it would means that we have already observed 2 heads and 2 tails before we see the actual data. This is a weak preference for the value of Œ∏=0.5\theta=0.5Œ∏=0.5Ôªø (small update in figure (a) below).
If we set a=b=1a=b=1a=b=1Ôªø, the prior become p(Œ∏)=Œ∏0(1‚àíŒ∏)0=Unif(Œ∏‚à£0,1)p(\theta)=\theta^{0}(1-\theta)^0=\mathrm{Unif}(\theta|0,1)p(Œ∏)=Œ∏0(1‚àíŒ∏)0=Unif(Œ∏‚à£0,1)Ôªø. The prior is uninformative, so there is no update.
Similarly to the MAP estimate already we saw in the regularization section, we have
Œ∏^map=a+N1‚àí1a+b+N‚àí2\hat{\theta}_{map}=\frac{a+N_1-1}{a+b+N-2}Œ∏^map‚Äã=a+b+N‚àí2a+N1‚Äã‚àí1‚Äã
If we use a=b=2a=b=2a=b=2Ôªø, we find back the add-one smoothing.
If we use a=b=1a=b=1a=b=1Ôªø, we have Œ∏^map=Œ∏^mle\hat{\theta}_{map}=\hat{\theta}_{mle}Œ∏^map‚Äã=Œ∏^mle‚ÄãÔªø
The posterior mean is a more robust estimation than the posterior mode since it integrates over the whole space (instead of a single point).
If p(Œ∏‚à£D)=Beta(Œ∏‚à£aÀò,bÀò)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|\breve{a},\breve{b})p(Œ∏‚à£D)=Beta(Œ∏‚à£aÀò,bÀò)Ôªø, the posterior mean is:
Œ∏Àâ‚âúE[Œ∏‚à£D]=aÀòNÀò\bar{\theta} \triangleq \mathbb{E}[\theta|\mathcal{D}]=\frac{\breve{a}}{\breve{N}}Œ∏Àâ‚âúE[Œ∏‚à£D]=NÀòaÀò‚Äã
with NÀò=aÀò+bÀò\breve{N}=\breve{a}+\breve{b}NÀò=aÀò+bÀòÔªø the strength of the posterior.
The posterior mean is a convex combination of the prior mean, m=aNabm=\frac{a}{N_{ab}}m=Nab‚Äãa‚ÄãÔªø and the MLE: Œ∏^mle=N1N\hat{\theta}_{mle}=\frac{N_1}{N}Œ∏^mle‚Äã=NN1‚Äã‚ÄãÔªø
Œ∏^map=a+N1a+b+N1+N0=NabN+NabaNab+NN+NabN1N=Œªm+(1‚àíŒª)Œ∏^mle\begin{align} \hat{\theta}_{map}&=\frac{a+N_1}{a+b+N_1+N_0}\\ &=\frac{N_{ab}}{N+N_{ab}}\frac{a}{N_{ab}}+\frac{N}{N+N_{ab}}\frac{N_1}{N} \\ &= \lambda m+(1-\lambda)\hat{\theta}_{mle} \end{align}Œ∏^map‚Äã‚Äã=a+b+N1‚Äã+N0‚Äãa+N1‚Äã‚Äã=N+Nab‚ÄãNab‚Äã‚ÄãNab‚Äãa‚Äã+N+Nab‚ÄãN‚ÄãNN1‚Äã‚Äã=Œªm+(1‚àíŒª)Œ∏^mle‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã
The variance of a Beta posterior is given by:
V[Œ∏‚à£D]=aÀòbÀò(aÀò+bÀò)2(aÀò+bÀò+1)‚âàN1N0N3=Œ∏(1‚àíŒ∏)N\mathbb{V}[\theta|\mathcal{D}]=\frac{\breve{a}\breve{b}}{(\breve{a}+\breve{b})^2(\breve{a}+\breve{b}+1)}\approx \frac{N_1N_0}{N^3}=\frac{\theta(1-\theta)}{N}V[Œ∏‚à£D]=(aÀò+bÀò)2(aÀò+bÀò+1)aÀòbÀò‚Äã‚âàN3N1‚ÄãN0‚Äã‚Äã=NŒ∏(1‚àíŒ∏)‚Äã
Thus, the standard error of our estimate (aka the posterior variance) is:
se(Œ∏)=V[Œ∏‚à£D]=Œ∏(1‚àíŒ∏)Nse(\theta)=\sqrt{\mathbb{V}[\theta|\mathcal{D}]}=\sqrt{\frac{\theta(1-\theta)}{N}}se(Œ∏)=V[Œ∏‚à£D]‚Äã=NŒ∏(1‚àíŒ∏)‚Äã‚Äã
For the Bernoulli distribution, the posterior predictive distribution has the form:
p(y=1‚à£D)=‚à´01p(y=1‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£D)dŒ∏=‚à´01Œ∏‚ÄâBeta(Œ∏‚à£a,b)dŒ∏=E[Œ∏‚à£D]=aÀòaÀò+bÀò\begin{align} p(y=1|\mathcal{D})&=\int^1_0 p(y=1|\theta)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})d\theta \\ &= \int^1_0\theta\, \mathrm{Beta} (\theta|a,b)d\theta \\ &= \mathbb{E}[\theta|\mathcal{D}] \\ &= \frac{\breve{a}}{\breve{a}+\breve{b}} \end{align} p(y=1‚à£D)‚Äã=‚à´01‚Äãp(y=1‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£D)dŒ∏=‚à´01‚ÄãŒ∏Beta(Œ∏‚à£a,b)dŒ∏=E[Œ∏‚à£D]=aÀò+bÀòaÀò‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã
For the Binomial distribution, the posterior predictive distribution has the form of the Beta-Binomial distribution:
p(y‚à£D,M)=‚à´01Bin(y‚à£M,Œ∏)‚ÄâBeta(Œ∏‚à£aÀò,bÀò)dŒ∏=(My)1B(aÀò,bÀò)‚à´01Œ∏y(1‚àíŒ∏)M‚àíyŒ∏aÀò‚àí1(1‚àíŒ∏)bÀò‚àí1dŒ∏=(My)B(y+aÀò,M‚àíy+bÀò)B(aÀò,bÀò)‚âúBb(y‚à£M,aÀò,bÀò)\begin{align} p(y|\mathcal{D},M)&=\int^1_0\mathrm{Bin}(y|M,\theta)\,\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|\breve{a},\breve{b})d\theta \\ &= \binom{M}{y}\frac{1}{\Beta(\breve{a},\breve{b})}\int^1_0\theta^y(1-\theta)^{M-y}\theta^{\breve{a}-1}(1-\theta)^{\breve{b}-1}d\theta \\ &=\binom{M}{y}\frac{\Beta(y+\breve{a},M-y+\breve{b})}{\Beta(\breve{a},\breve{b})} \\ &\triangleq \mathrm{Bb}(y|M,\breve{a},\breve{b}) \end{align}p(y‚à£D,M)‚Äã=‚à´01‚ÄãBin(y‚à£M,Œ∏)Beta(Œ∏‚à£aÀò,bÀò)dŒ∏=(yM‚Äã)B(aÀò,bÀò)1‚Äã‚à´01‚ÄãŒ∏y(1‚àíŒ∏)M‚àíyŒ∏aÀò‚àí1(1‚àíŒ∏)bÀò‚àí1dŒ∏=(yM‚Äã)B(aÀò,bÀò)B(y+aÀò,M‚àíy+bÀò)‚Äã‚âúBb(y‚à£M,aÀò,bÀò)‚Äã‚Äã
We plot in figure (a) below the posterior predictive distribution for M=10,N1=4,N0=1M=10,N_1=4,N_0=1M=10,N1‚Äã=4,N0‚Äã=1Ôªø, with a uniform prior Beta(Œ∏‚à£1,1)\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|1,1)Beta(Œ∏‚à£1,1)Ôªø.
(Remember that aÀò=a+N1\breve{a}=a+N_1aÀò=a+N1‚ÄãÔªø and bÀò=b+N0\breve{b}=b+N_0bÀò=b+N0‚ÄãÔªø)
We plot in figure (b) the plugin approximation, where Œ∏^map\hat{\theta}_{map}Œ∏^map‚ÄãÔªø is directly injected into the likelihood: p(y‚à£D,M)=Bin(y‚à£M,Œ∏^map)p(y|\mathcal{D},M)=\mathrm{Bin}(y|M,\hat{\theta}_{map})p(y‚à£D,M)=Bin(y‚à£M,Œ∏^map‚Äã)Ôªø
The long tail of the Bayesian approach makes more less prone to overfitting and Black Swan paradoxes. In both case, the prior is uniform, so this Bayesian property is due to the integration over unknown parameters.
The marginal likelihood for a model M\mathcal{M}MÔªø is defined as:
p(D‚à£M)=‚à´p(D‚à£Œ∏,M)p(Œ∏‚à£M)dŒ∏p(\mathcal{D|M})=\int p(\mathcal{D}|\theta,\mathcal{M})p(\theta|\mathcal{M})d\thetap(D‚à£M)=‚à´p(D‚à£Œ∏,M)p(Œ∏‚à£M)dŒ∏
Since it is constant in Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø it is not useful for parameter inference, but can help for model or hyperparameters selection (aka Empirical Bayes)
The marginal likelihood for the Beta Binomial is
p(Œ∏‚à£D)=p(D‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏)p(D)=(NN1)1p(D)1B(a,b)Œ∏a+N1‚àí1(1‚àíŒ∏)b+N0‚àí11B(a+N1,b+N0)=(NN1)1p(D)1B(a,b)p(D)=(NN1)B(a+N1,b+N0)B(a,b)\begin{align} p(\theta|\mathcal{D})&=\frac{p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(\theta)}{p(\mathcal{D})} \\ &= \binom{N}{N_1}\frac{1}{p(\mathcal{D})}\frac{1}{\Beta(a,b)}\theta^{a+N_1-1}(1-\theta)^{b+N_0-1} \\ \frac{1}{\Beta(a+N_1, b+N_0)}&=\binom{N}{N_1}\frac{1}{p(\mathcal{D})}\frac{1}{\Beta(a,b)} \\ p(\mathcal{D})&= \binom{N}{N_1}\frac{\Beta(a+N_1,b+N_0)}{\Beta(a,b)} \end{align}p(Œ∏‚à£D)B(a+N1‚Äã,b+N0‚Äã)1‚Äãp(D)‚Äã=p(D)p(D‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏)‚Äã=(N1‚ÄãN‚Äã)p(D)1‚ÄãB(a,b)1‚ÄãŒ∏a+N1‚Äã‚àí1(1‚àíŒ∏)b+N0‚Äã‚àí1=(N1‚ÄãN‚Äã)p(D)1‚ÄãB(a,b)1‚Äã=(N1‚ÄãN‚Äã)B(a,b)B(a+N1‚Äã,b+N0‚Äã)‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã
Our current prior is rather restrictive. If we want to represent a coin that may be fair but also be equally biased towards head. We can use a Mixture of beta distributions:
p(Œ∏)=0.5‚ÄâBeta(20,20)+0.5‚ÄâBeta(30,10)p(\theta)=0.5\,\mathrm{Beta}(20,20)+0.5\,\mathrm{Beta}(30,10)p(Œ∏)=0.5Beta(20,20)+0.5Beta(30,10)
We introduce h=kh=kh=kÔªø meaning that Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø comes from mixture hhhÔªø, so the mixture prior is:
p(Œ∏)=‚àëkp(h=k)p(Œ∏‚à£h=k)p(\theta)=\sum_k p(h=k)p(\theta|h=k)p(Œ∏)=k‚àë‚Äãp(h=k)p(Œ∏‚à£h=k)
We can show that the posterior can also be written as a mixture of conjugate distributions:
p(Œ∏‚à£D)=‚àëkp(h=k‚à£D)p(Œ∏‚à£D,h=k)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=\sum_k p(h=k|\mathcal{D})p(\theta|\mathcal{D},h=k)p(Œ∏‚à£D)=k‚àë‚Äãp(h=k‚à£D)p(Œ∏‚à£D,h=k)
where the posterior mixing weights are:
p(h=k‚à£D)=p(D‚à£h=k)p(h=k)‚àëk‚Ä≤p(D‚à£h=k‚Ä≤)p(h=k‚Ä≤)p(h=k|\mathcal{D})=\frac{p(\mathcal{D}|h=k)p(h=k)}{\sum_{k'}p(\mathcal{D}|h=k')p(h=k')}p(h=k‚à£D)=‚àëk‚Ä≤‚Äãp(D‚à£h=k‚Ä≤)p(h=k‚Ä≤)p(D‚à£h=k)p(h=k)‚Äã
We can compute this quantity using the equation (40) of the marginal likelihood. If we observe N1=20N_1=20N1‚Äã=20Ôªø heads and N0=10N_0=10N0‚Äã=10Ôªø tails, the posterior is:
p(Œ∏‚à£D)=0.346‚ÄâBeta(Œ∏‚à£40,30)+0.654‚ÄâBeta(Œ∏‚à£50,20)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=0.346\,\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|40,30)+0.654\,\mathrm{Beta}(\theta|50,20)p(Œ∏‚à£D)=0.346Beta(Œ∏‚à£40,30)+0.654Beta(Œ∏‚à£50,20)
We can compute the probability that the coin is biased towards head:
Pr‚Å°(Œ∏>0.5‚à£D)=‚àëkPr‚Å°(Œ∏>0.5‚à£D,h=k)p(h=k‚à£D)=0.9604\Pr(\theta>0.5|\mathcal{D})=\sum_k\Pr(\theta>0.5|\mathcal{D},h=k)p(h=k|\mathcal{D})=0.9604Pr(Œ∏>0.5‚à£D)=k‚àë‚ÄãPr(Œ∏>0.5‚à£D,h=k)p(h=k‚à£D)=0.9604
4.6.3 The Dirichlet-multinomial model
We generalize the results from binary variable to categories (e.g. dice). The likelihood is:
p(D‚à£Œ∏)=‚àèn=1nCat(yn‚à£Œ∏)=‚àèn=1N‚àèc=1CŒ∏cI(yn=c)=‚àèc=1CŒ∏cNcp(\mathcal{D}|\theta)=\prod^n_{n=1}\mathrm{Cat}(y_n|\theta)=\prod^N_{n=1}\prod^C_{c=1}\theta_c^{\mathbb{I}(y_n=c)}=\prod^C_{c=1} \theta_c^{N_c}p(D‚à£Œ∏)=n=1‚àèn‚ÄãCat(yn‚Äã‚à£Œ∏)=n=1‚àèN‚Äãc=1‚àèC‚ÄãŒ∏cI(yn‚Äã=c)‚Äã=c=1‚àèC‚ÄãŒ∏cNc‚Äã‚Äã
The conjugate prior is a Dirichlet distribution, which is a multivariate of a beta distribution. It has support over the probability simplex:
SK={Œ∏:0‚â§Œ∏k‚â§1,‚àëk=1KŒ∏=1}S_K=\{\theta:0\leq\theta_k\leq1, \sum^K_{k=1}\theta=1 \}SK‚Äã={Œ∏:0‚â§Œ∏k‚Äã‚â§1,k=1‚àëK‚ÄãŒ∏=1}
The pdf of Dirichlet:
Dir(Œ∏‚à£a)=1B(a)‚àèk=1KŒ∏kak‚àí1I(Œ∏‚ààSK)\mathrm{Dir}(\theta|\bold{a})=\frac{1}{\Beta(\bold{a})}\prod_{k=1}^K\theta_k^{a_k-1}\mathbb{I}(\theta \in S_K)Dir(Œ∏‚à£a)=B(a)1‚Äãk=1‚àèK‚ÄãŒ∏kak‚Äã‚àí1‚ÄãI(Œ∏‚ààSK‚Äã)
with the multivariate Beta function:
B(a)=‚àëk=1KŒì(ak)Œì(‚àëk=1Kak)\Beta(\bold{a})=\frac{\sum_{k=1}^K\Gamma(a_k)}{\Gamma({\sum_{k=1}^Ka_k})}B(a)=Œì(‚àëk=1K‚Äãak‚Äã)‚àëk=1K‚ÄãŒì(ak‚Äã)‚Äã
The posterior is:
p(Œ∏‚à£D)‚àùp(D‚à£Œ∏)Dir(Œ∏‚à£a)=‚àèkŒ∏kNk‚àèkŒ∏kak‚àí1=Dir(Œ∏‚à£a1+N1,...,aK+Nk)=Dir(Œ∏‚à£aÀò)\begin{align} p(\theta|\mathcal{D})&\propto p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)\mathrm{Dir}(\theta|\bold{a}) \\ &= \prod_k \theta_k^{N_k} \prod_k\theta_k^{a_k-1} \\ &= \mathrm{Dir}(\theta|a_1+N_1,...,a_K+N_k)\\ &= \mathrm{Dir}(\theta|\breve{\bold{a}}) \end{align} p(Œ∏‚à£D)‚Äã‚àùp(D‚à£Œ∏)Dir(Œ∏‚à£a)=k‚àè‚ÄãŒ∏kNk‚Äã‚Äãk‚àè‚ÄãŒ∏kak‚Äã‚àí1‚Äã=Dir(Œ∏‚à£a1‚Äã+N1‚Äã,...,aK‚Äã+Nk‚Äã)=Dir(Œ∏‚à£aÀò)‚Äã‚Äã
The posterior mean is:
Œ∏Àâk=aÀòk‚àëk‚Ä≤=1KaÀòk‚Ä≤\bar{\theta}_k=\frac{\breve{a}_k}{\sum^K_{k'=1}\breve{a}_{k'}}Œ∏Àâk‚Äã=‚àëk‚Ä≤=1K‚ÄãaÀòk‚Ä≤‚ÄãaÀòk‚Äã‚Äã
The posterior mode (which corresponds to the MAP) is:
Œ∏^k=aÀòk‚àí1‚àëk‚Ä≤=1K(aÀòk‚Ä≤‚àí1)\hat{\theta}_k=\frac{\breve{a}_k-1}{\sum_{k'=1}^K(\breve{a}_{k'}-1)}Œ∏^k‚Äã=‚àëk‚Ä≤=1K‚Äã(aÀòk‚Ä≤‚Äã‚àí1)aÀòk‚Äã‚àí1‚Äã
If ak=1a_k=1ak‚Äã=1Ôªø, corresponding to a uniform prior, the MAP becomes the MLE:
Œ∏k=NkN\theta_k=\frac{N_k}{N}Œ∏k‚Äã=NNk‚Äã‚Äã
The posterior predictive distribution is given by:
p(y=k‚à£D)=‚à´p(y=k‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£D)dŒ∏=‚à´Œ∏kp(Œ∏k‚à£D)dŒ∏k=E[Œ∏k‚à£D]=aÀòk‚àëk‚Ä≤aÀòk‚Ä≤\begin{align} p(y=k|\mathcal{D}) &= \int p(y=k|\theta)p(\theta |\mathcal{D})d\theta \\ &= \int \theta_k p(\theta_k|\mathcal{D})d\theta_k = \mathbb{E}[\theta_k|\mathcal{D}]=\frac{\breve{a}_k}{\sum_{k'}\breve{a}_{k'}} \end{align}p(y=k‚à£D)‚Äã=‚à´p(y=k‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£D)dŒ∏=‚à´Œ∏k‚Äãp(Œ∏k‚Äã‚à£D)dŒ∏k‚Äã=E[Œ∏k‚Äã‚à£D]=‚àëk‚Ä≤‚ÄãaÀòk‚Ä≤‚ÄãaÀòk‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã
For a batch of data to predict, it becomes
p(y~‚à£y)=p(y,y~)p(y)p(\bold{\tilde{y}|y})=\frac{p(\bold{y,\tilde{y}})}{p(\bold{y})}p(y~‚Äã‚à£y)=p(y)p(y,y~‚Äã)‚Äã
Where the numerator and the denominator are marginal likelihoods, given by:
p(D)=B(a+N)B(a)p(\mathcal{D})=\frac{\Beta(\bold{a}+N)}{\Beta(\bold{a})}p(D)=B(a)B(a+N)‚Äã
4.6.4 Gaussian-Gaussian model
We derive the posterior for the parameters for a Gaussian distribution, assuming that the variance is known for simplicity.
We can show that the conjugate prior is also Gaussian. We then apply the Bayes rule for Gaussian, with the observed precision Œ∫\kappaŒ∫Ôªø and the prior precision Œª\lambdaŒªÔªø. The posterior is:
p(Œº‚à£D,Œ∫‚àí1)=N(Œº‚à£mÀò,ŒªÀò‚àí1)ŒªÀò=Œª+NŒ∫mÀò=NŒ∫yÀâ+ŒªmŒªÀò=NŒ∫Œª+NŒ∫yÀâ+ŒªŒª+NŒ∫m\begin{align} p(\mu|\mathcal{D},\kappa^{-1}) &= \mathcal{N}(\mu|\breve{m},\breve{\lambda}^{-1}) \\ \breve{\lambda} &= \lambda +N \kappa \\ \breve{m} &= \frac{N \kappa \bar{y}+\lambda m}{\breve{\lambda}}=\frac{N \kappa}{\lambda+N\kappa}\bar{y}+\frac{\lambda}{\lambda+N\kappa}m \end{align}p(Œº‚à£D,Œ∫‚àí1)ŒªÀòmÀò‚Äã=N(Œº‚à£mÀò,ŒªÀò‚àí1)=Œª+NŒ∫=ŒªÀòNŒ∫yÀâ‚Äã+Œªm‚Äã=Œª+NŒ∫NŒ∫‚ÄãyÀâ‚Äã+Œª+NŒ∫Œª‚Äãm‚Äã‚Äã
The posterior mean is a convex combination of the empirical mean and the prior mean.
To gain more intuition, after seeing N=1N=1N=1Ôªø point, our posterior mean is:
mÀò=Œ∫ŒªÀòy+ŒªŒªÀòm=m+Œ∫ŒªÀò(y‚àím)=y‚àíŒªŒªÀò(y‚àím)\begin{align} \breve{m} &=\frac{\kappa}{\breve{\lambda}}y+\frac{\lambda}{\breve{\lambda}}m \\ &= m + \frac{\kappa}{\breve{\lambda}}(y-m) \\ &= y-\frac{\lambda}{\breve{\lambda}}(y-m) \end{align}mÀò‚Äã=ŒªÀòŒ∫‚Äãy+ŒªÀòŒª‚Äãm=m+ŒªÀòŒ∫‚Äã(y‚àím)=y‚àíŒªÀòŒª‚Äã(y‚àím)‚Äã‚Äã
The second equation is the prior mean adjusted towards the data y.
The third equation is the data adjusted towards the prior mean, called a shrinkage estimate.
For a Gaussian estimate the posterior mean and posterior mode are the same, thus we can use the above equations to perform MAP estimation.
If we set an uninformative prior Œª=0\lambda=0Œª=0Ôªø and approximate the observed variance œÉ2\sigma^2œÉ2Ôªø by
s2=1N‚àën=1N(yn‚àíyÀâ)s^2=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^N(y_n-\bar{y})s2=N1‚Äãn=1‚àëN‚Äã(yn‚Äã‚àíyÀâ‚Äã)
then the posterior variance of our mean estimate is:
se(Œº)=V[Œº‚à£D]=1ŒªÀò=sNse(\mu)=\sqrt{\mathbb{V}[\mu|\mathcal{D}]}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\breve{\lambda}}}=\frac{s}{\sqrt{N}}se(Œº)=V[Œº‚à£D]‚Äã=ŒªÀò‚Äã1‚Äã=N‚Äãs‚Äã
We see that uncertainty in Œº\muŒºÔªø reduces at the rate 1/N1/\sqrt{N}1/N‚ÄãÔªø.
Because 95% of the Gaussian distribution is contained within 2 standard deviations of the mean, the 95% credible interval for Œº\muŒºÔªø is:
I.95(Œº‚à£D)=yÀâ¬±2sNI_{.95}(\mu|\mathcal{D})=\bar{y} ¬± 2\frac{s}{\sqrt{N}}I.95‚Äã(Œº‚à£D)=yÀâ‚Äã¬±2N‚Äãs‚Äã
In the multivariate case, the likelihood becomes:
p(D‚à£Œº)=‚àèn=1NN(yn‚à£Œº,Œ£)=N(2œÄ)D/2‚à£Œ£‚à£1/2exp‚Å°(‚àí12‚àën=1N(yn‚àíŒº)‚ä§Œ£‚àí1(yn‚àíŒº))=N(yÀâ‚à£Œº,1NŒ£)\begin{align} p(\mathcal{D}|\mu)&=\prod_{n=1}^N \mathcal{N}(\bold{y}_n|\mu,\Sigma) \\ &= \frac{N}{(2\pi)^{D/2}|\Sigma|^{1/2}}\exp\big( -\frac{1}{2}\sum_{n=1}^N(\bold{y}_n-\mu)^\top\Sigma^{-1}(\bold{y}_n-\mu) \big) \\ &= \mathcal{N}(\bold{\bar{y}}|\mu,\frac{1}{N}\Sigma) \end{align}p(D‚à£Œº)‚Äã=n=1‚àèN‚ÄãN(yn‚Äã‚à£Œº,Œ£)=(2œÄ)D/2‚à£Œ£‚à£1/2N‚Äãexp(‚àí21‚Äãn=1‚àëN‚Äã(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº)‚ä§Œ£‚àí1(yn‚Äã‚àíŒº))=N(yÀâ‚Äã‚à£Œº,N1‚ÄãŒ£)‚Äã‚Äã
Thus we replace the set of observations with their mean and scale down the covariance.
We obtain the same expression for the posterior of the mean than in the univariate case.
4.6.5 Beyond conjugate priors
For most models, there is no prior in the exponential family that conjugates to the likelihood. We briefly discuss various other kinds of prior.
Non informative prior
When we have little to no domain specific knowledge, we prefer ‚Äúlet the data speak for itself‚Äù (we get closer to the frequentist statistics).
We can for exemple use a flat prior p(Œº)‚àù1p(\mu) \propto1p(Œº)‚àù1Ôªø, which can be viewed as an infinitely wide Gaussian.
Hierarchical prior
The parameters of the prior p(Œ∏)p(\theta)p(Œ∏)Ôªø are called hyper-parameters œï\phiœïÔªø. If there are unknown, we can put a prior on them: this defines a hierarchical Bayesian model.
If we set a non informative prior on œï\phiœïÔªø, the joint distribution has the form:
p(œï,Œ∏,D)=p(D‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£œï)p(œï)p(\phi,\theta,\mathcal{D})=p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(\theta|\phi)p(\phi)p(œï,Œ∏,D)=p(D‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£œï)p(œï)
We aim at learning œï\phiœïÔªø by treating the parameters as data points. This is useful when we want to estimate multiple related parameters from different subpopulations.
Empirical prior
The joint distribution of the hierarchical prior can be challenging to compute.
Instead, we make a point wise estimation of the hyper-parameters by maximizing the marginal likelihood:
œï^mml(D)=arg‚Äâmax‚Å°œïp(D‚à£œï)=arg‚Äâmax‚Å°œï‚à´p(D‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£œï)dŒ∏\hat{\phi}_{mml}(\mathcal{D})=\argmax _{\phi}p(\mathcal{D}|\phi)=\argmax_{\phi}\int p(\mathcal{D}|\theta)p(\theta|\phi)d\thetaœï^‚Äãmml‚Äã(D)=œïargmax‚Äãp(D‚à£œï)=œïargmax‚Äã‚à´p(D‚à£Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£œï)dŒ∏
We then compute the conditional posterior p(Œ∏‚à£œï^,D)p(\theta|\hat{\phi},\mathcal{D})p(Œ∏‚à£œï^‚Äã,D)Ôªø in the usual way.
This violates the principle that the prior should be chosen independently of the data, but we can view it as a computationally cheap approximation of the hierarchical prior.
The more integral one performs, the ‚Äúmore Bayesian‚Äù one becomes:
Note that ML-II is less likely to overfit than ML since there are often fewer hyper-parameters œï\phiœïÔªø than parameters Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø.
4.6.6 Credible intervals
The posterior distribution is hard to represent in high dimension. We can summarize it via a point estimate (posterior mean or mode) and compute the associated credible interval (which is different from the frequentist confidence interval).
The Credible Interval for 100(1‚àíŒ±)%100(1-\alpha)\%100(1‚àíŒ±)%Ôªø is:
CŒ±(D)=(‚Ñì,u):P(‚Ñì‚â§Œ∏‚â§u‚à£D)=1‚àíŒ±C_{\alpha}(\mathcal{D})=(\ell, u):P(\ell \leq \theta \leq u|\mathcal{D})=1-\alphaCŒ±‚Äã(D)=(‚Ñì,u):P(‚Ñì‚â§Œ∏‚â§u‚à£D)=1‚àíŒ±
If the posterior has a known functional form, we can compute its inverse cdf to find the interval: ‚Ñì=F‚àí1(Œ±/2)\ell=F^{-1}(\alpha/2)‚Ñì=F‚àí1(Œ±/2)Ôªø and u=F‚àí1(1‚àíŒ±/2)u=F^{-1}(1-\alpha/2)u=F‚àí1(1‚àíŒ±/2)Ôªø.
In general, finding the inverse cdf is hard, so instead we rank samples from the posterior distribution and select our target percentiles.
Sometimes, points that are outside the interval have higher density probability than inner points.
We use the highest posterior density (HPD) to counter this, by finding the threshold p‚àóp^*p‚àóÔªø:
1‚àíŒ±=‚à´Œ∏:p(Œ∏‚à£D)>p‚àóp(Œ∏‚à£D)dŒ∏1-\alpha=\int_{\theta:p(\theta|\mathcal{D})> p^*}p(\theta|\mathcal{D})d\theta1‚àíŒ±=‚à´Œ∏:p(Œ∏‚à£D)>p‚àó‚Äãp(Œ∏‚à£D)dŒ∏
and then defines the HPD as:
CŒ±(D)=Œ∏:p(Œ∏‚à£D)‚â•p‚àóC_{\alpha}(\mathcal{D})=\theta:p(\theta|\mathcal{D})\geq p^*CŒ±‚Äã(D)=Œ∏:p(Œ∏‚à£D)‚â•p‚àó
4.6.7 Bayesian machine learning
So far, we have focused on unconditional models of the form p(y‚à£Œ∏)p(y|\theta)p(y‚à£Œ∏)Ôªø.
In supervised machine learning, we focus on conditional models of the form p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)p(y|x,\theta)p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)Ôªø.
Our posterior becomes p(Œ∏‚à£D)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})p(Œ∏‚à£D)Ôªø with D={(xn,yn):n=1:N}\mathcal{D}=\{(x_n,y_n):n=1:N\}D={(xn‚Äã,yn‚Äã):n=1:N}Ôªø
Once we have computed the posterior over the Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø, we can compute the posterior predictive distribution over yyyÔªø given xxxÔªø:
p(y‚à£x,D)=‚à´p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£D)dŒ∏p(y|x,\mathcal{D})=\int p(y|x,\theta)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})d\theta p(y‚à£x,D)=‚à´p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)p(Œ∏‚à£D)dŒ∏
Computing this integral is often intractable. Instead, we approximate that there is a single best model Œ∏^\hat{\theta}Œ∏^Ôªø, such as the MLE.
p(Œ∏‚à£D)=Œ¥(Œ∏‚àíŒ∏^)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})=\delta(\theta-\hat{\theta})p(Œ∏‚à£D)=Œ¥(Œ∏‚àíŒ∏^)
Using the plugin approximation, the predictive distribution is now:
p(y‚à£x,D)‚âà‚à´p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)Œ¥(Œ∏‚àíŒ∏^)dŒ∏=p(y‚à£x,Œ∏^)p(y|x,\mathcal{D})\approx\int p(y|x,\theta)\delta(\theta-\hat{\theta})d\theta=p(y|x,\hat{\theta})p(y‚à£x,D)‚âà‚à´p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)Œ¥(Œ∏‚àíŒ∏^)dŒ∏=p(y‚à£x,Œ∏^)
This is the standard machine learning approach of fitting a model Œ∏^\hat{\theta}Œ∏^Ôªø then making prediction.
However, as this approximation can overfit, we average over a few plausible parameters values (instead of the fully Bayesian approach above). Here are 2 examples:
Scalar input, binary output
To perform binary classification, we can use a logistic regression of the form:
p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)=Ber(y‚à£œÉ(w‚ä§x+b))p(y|x,\theta)=\mathrm{Ber}(y|\sigma(w^\top x+b))p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)=Ber(y‚à£œÉ(w‚ä§x+b))
In other words:
p(y=1‚à£x,Œ∏)=œÉ(w‚ä§x+b)=11+e‚àíw‚ä§x+bp(y=1|x,\theta)=\sigma(w^\top x+b)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-w^\top x + b}}p(y=1‚à£x,Œ∏)=œÉ(w‚ä§x+b)=1+e‚àíw‚ä§x+b1‚Äã
We find the MLE Œ∏^\hat{\theta}Œ∏^Ôªø for this 1d logistic regression and use the plugin approximation to get the posterior predictive p(y=1‚à£x,Œ∏^)p(y=1|x,\hat{\theta})p(y=1‚à£x,Œ∏^)Ôªø
The decision boundary is defined as:
œÉ(w‚ä§x‚àó+b)=1/2‚áíx‚àó=‚àíbw\sigma(w^\top x^* + b)=1/2 \Rightarrow x^*=-\frac{b}{w}œÉ(w‚ä§x‚àó+b)=1/2‚áíx‚àó=‚àíwb‚Äã
We capture the uncertainty by approximating the posterior p(Œ∏‚à£D)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})p(Œ∏‚à£D)Ôªø.
Given this, we can approximate the mean and the 95% credible interval of the posterior predictive distribution using a Monte Carlo approximation:
p(y=1‚à£x,D)‚âà1S‚àës=1Sp(y=1‚à£x,Œ∏s)CŒ±(x,D)={Œ∏s:p(Œ∏s‚à£x,D)>p‚àó}\begin{align}p(y=1|x,\mathcal{D})&\approx \frac{1}{S}\sum_{s=1}^Sp(y=1|x,\theta_s) \\ C_{\alpha}(x,\mathcal{D}) &= \{\theta_s:p(\theta_s|x,\mathcal{D})> p^*\} \end{align}p(y=1‚à£x,D)CŒ±‚Äã(x,D)‚Äã‚âàS1‚Äãs=1‚àëS‚Äãp(y=1‚à£x,Œ∏s‚Äã)={Œ∏s‚Äã:p(Œ∏s‚Äã‚à£x,D)>p‚àó}‚Äã‚Äã
where Œ∏s‚àºp(Œ∏‚à£D)\theta_s \sim p(\theta|\mathcal{D})Œ∏s‚Äã‚àºp(Œ∏‚à£D)Ôªø is a posterior sample.
We can also compute a distribution over the decision boundary:
p(x‚àó‚à£D)=1S‚àës=1SŒ¥(x‚àó‚àí(‚àíbsws))p(x^*|\mathcal{D})=\frac{1}{S}\sum_{s=1}^S \delta(x^*-(-\frac{b_s}{w_s}))p(x‚àó‚à£D)=S1‚Äãs=1‚àëS‚ÄãŒ¥(x‚àó‚àí(‚àíws‚Äãbs‚Äã‚Äã))
where (bs,ws)=Œ∏s(b_s,w_s)=\theta_s(bs‚Äã,ws‚Äã)=Œ∏s‚ÄãÔªø
Binary input, scalar output
We now predict the delivery time yyyÔªø for a package from company A (x=0x=0x=0Ôªø) or company B (x=1x=1x=1Ôªø).
Our model is:
p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)=N(y‚à£Œºx,œÉx2)p(y|x,\theta)=\mathcal{N}(y|\mu_x,\sigma^2_x)p(y‚à£x,Œ∏)=N(y‚à£Œºx‚Äã,œÉx2‚Äã)
The parameters are Œ∏=(Œº0,Œº1,œÉ0,œÉ1)\theta=(\mu_0, \mu_1, \sigma_0, \sigma_1)Œ∏=(Œº0‚Äã,Œº1‚Äã,œÉ0‚Äã,œÉ1‚Äã)Ôªø so we can fit this model using MLE.
However, the issue with the plug-in approximation p(y‚à£x,Œ∏^)p(y|x,\hat{\theta})p(y‚à£x,Œ∏^)Ôªø is that in the case of one single point of observation, we don‚Äôt capture uncertainty, our MLE for standard deviations are œÉ^0=œÉ^1=0\hat{\sigma}_0=\hat{\sigma}_1=0œÉ^0‚Äã=œÉ^1‚Äã=0Ôªø.
Instead, the Bayesian approach using the Bayes rule for Gaussian allows to compute the posterior variance and the credible interval.
4.6.8 Computational issues
Usually, performing the Bayesian update is intractable except for simple cases like conjugate models or latent variables with few possible values.
We perform approximate posterior inference for a Beta-Bernoulli model:
p(Œ∏‚à£D)‚àù[‚àèn=1NBin(yn‚à£Œ∏)]Beta(Œ∏‚à£a,b)p(\theta|\mathcal{D})\propto \Bigg[\prod_{n=1}^N \mathrm{Bin}(y_n|\theta)\Bigg] \mathrm{Beta}(\theta | a, b)p(Œ∏‚à£D)‚àù[n=1‚àèN‚ÄãBin(yn‚Äã‚à£Œ∏)]Beta(Œ∏‚à£a,b)
with D\mathcal{D}DÔªø consisting in 10 heads and 1 tails, with a uniform prior.
Grid approximation
The simplest approach is to partition Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø in a finite set Œ∏1,...,Œ∏K\theta_1,...,\theta_KŒ∏1‚Äã,...,Œ∏K‚ÄãÔªø and approximate the posterior by brute-force enumeration:
p(Œ∏=Œ∏k‚à£D)=p(D‚à£Œ∏k)p(Œ∏k)‚àëk‚Ä≤=1Kp(D‚à£Œ∏k‚Ä≤)p(Œ∏k‚Ä≤)p(\theta=\theta_k|\mathcal{D})=\frac{p(\mathcal{D} | \theta_k)p(\theta_k)}{\sum_{k'=1}^K p(\mathcal{D}|\theta_{k'})p(\theta_{k'})}p(Œ∏=Œ∏k‚Äã‚à£D)=‚àëk‚Ä≤=1K‚Äãp(D‚à£Œ∏k‚Ä≤‚Äã)p(Œ∏k‚Ä≤‚Äã)p(D‚à£Œ∏k‚Äã)p(Œ∏k‚Äã)‚Äã
This captures the skewness of our posterior, but the number of grid points scales exponentially in high dimension.
Laplace approximation
We approximate the posterior using a multivariate Gaussian as follow:
p(Œ∏‚à£D)‚âà1Zq(Œ∏)p(\theta|\mathcal{D}) \approx \frac{1}{Z}q(\theta)p(Œ∏‚à£D)‚âàZ1‚Äãq(Œ∏)
where Z=p(D)Z=p(\mathcal{D})Z=p(D)Ôªø and q(Œ∏)=N(Œ∏‚à£Œº,Œ£)q(\theta)=\mathcal{N}(\theta|\mu,\Sigma)q(Œ∏)=N(Œ∏‚à£Œº,Œ£)Ôªø
We can show that:
q(Œ∏)=N(Œ∏‚à£Œº=Œ∏^map,Œ£=H)Z=p(Œ∏^map,D)(2œÄ)D/2‚à£H‚à£‚àí1/2\begin{align} q(\theta)&=\mathcal{N}(\theta|\mu=\hat{\theta}_{map},\Sigma=H) \\ Z &= p(\hat{\theta}_{map},\mathcal{D}) (2\pi)^{D/2}|H|^{-1/2} \end{align}q(Œ∏)Z‚Äã=N(Œ∏‚à£Œº=Œ∏^map‚Äã,Œ£=H)=p(Œ∏^map‚Äã,D)(2œÄ)D/2‚à£H‚à£‚àí1/2‚Äã‚Äã
This is easy to apply, since after computing the MAP estimate, we just need to compute the Hessian at the mode (in high dimensional space, we use a diagonal approximation).
However we see that the Laplace approximation fits poorly when the posterior is skewed (whereas Gaussian is symmetric).
We can improve the fit by replacing the variable: Œ±=logit‚ÄâŒ∏\alpha=\mathrm{logit}\, \thetaŒ±=logitŒ∏Ôªø
Variational inference (VI)
VI is another optimization base posterior approximation. It aims at minimizing some discrepancy DDDÔªø between our posterior distribution pppÔªø and a distribution qqqÔªø from some tractable family (like MVN):
q‚àó=arg‚Äâmin‚Å°q‚ààQD(q,p)q^*=\argmin_{q \in \mathcal{Q}} D(q,p)q‚àó=q‚ààQargmin‚ÄãD(q,p)
If DDDÔªø is the KL divergence, we can derivate the evidence lower bound (ELBO) of the marginal likelihood. Maximizing the ELBO improves the posterior approximation.
Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC)
Although VI is fast, it can give a biased approximation since it is restricted to a specific function form q‚ààQq\in\mathcal{Q}q‚ààQÔªø.
Monte Carlo is a more flexible, non-parametric approach:
q(Œ∏)=1S‚àës=1SŒ¥(Œ∏‚àíŒ∏s)q(\theta)=\frac{1}{S}\sum^S_{s=1}\delta(\theta-\theta_s)q(Œ∏)=S1‚Äãs=1‚àëS‚ÄãŒ¥(Œ∏‚àíŒ∏s‚Äã)
The key issue is to create posterior samples Œ∏s‚àºp(Œ∏‚à£D)\theta_s \sim p(\theta|\mathcal{D})Œ∏s‚Äã‚àºp(Œ∏‚à£D)Ôªø without having to evaluate the normalization constant p(D)=‚à´p(Œ∏,D)dŒ∏p(\mathcal{D})=\int p(\theta,\mathcal{D})d\thetap(D)=‚à´p(Œ∏,D)dŒ∏Ôªø
MCMC ‚Äîand Hamiltonian Monte Carlo (HMC)‚Äî speeds up this method by augmenting this algorithm with gradient based information derived from ‚àálog‚Å°p(Œ∏,D)\nabla \log p(\theta,\mathcal{D})‚àálogp(Œ∏,D)Ôªø.
4.7 Frequentist statistics
4.7.1 Sampling distribution
In frequentist statistics, uncertainty is represented by the sampling distribution on an estimator.
An estimator is a decision procedure mapping observed data to an action (here the action is a parameter vector).
We denote it by Œ∏^=œÄ(D)\hat{\theta}=\pi(\mathcal{D})Œ∏^=œÄ(D)Ôªø, where Œ∏^\hat{\theta}Œ∏^Ôªø can be the MLE, MAP estimate or MOM estimate.
The sampling distribution is the distribution of results if we applied the estimator multiple times to different datasets from some distribution
We sample SSSÔªø different datasets of size NNNÔªø from some true model p(x‚à£Œ∏‚àó)p(x|\theta^*)p(x‚à£Œ∏‚àó)Ôªø:
D~(s)={xn‚àºp(xn‚à£Œ∏‚àó):n=1:N}\tilde{\mathcal{D}}^{(s)}=\{x_n \sim p(x_n|\theta^*):n=1:N\}D~(s)={xn‚Äã‚àºp(xn‚Äã‚à£Œ∏‚àó):n=1:N}
For brevity, we denote it D(s)‚àºŒ∏‚àó\mathcal{D}^{(s)} \sim \theta^*D(s)‚àºŒ∏‚àóÔªø
If we apply the estimator to each D(s)\mathcal{D}^{(s)}D(s)Ôªø:
p(œÄ(D~)=Œ∏‚à£D~‚àºŒ∏‚àó)‚âà1S‚àës=1SŒ¥(Œ∏=œÄ(D(s)))p(\pi(\mathcal{\tilde{D}})=\theta|\mathcal{\tilde{D}}\sim \theta^*) \approx \frac{1}{S} \sum^S_{s=1} \delta (\theta=\pi(\mathcal{D}^{(s)}))p(œÄ(D~)=Œ∏‚à£D~‚àºŒ∏‚àó)‚âàS1‚Äãs=1‚àëS‚ÄãŒ¥(Œ∏=œÄ(D(s)))
We typically need to approximate it with Monte Carlo.
4.7.2 Gaussian approximation of the sampling distribution of the MLE
The most common estimator is the MLE.
When the sample size becomes large, the sampling distribution of the MLE becomes Gaussian:
p(œÄ(D^)=Œ∏^‚à£D^‚àºŒ∏‚àó)‚ÜíN(Œ∏^‚à£Œ∏‚àó,(NF(Œ∏‚àó))‚àí1)p(\pi(\mathcal{\hat{D}})=\hat{\theta}|\mathcal{\hat{D}}\sim \theta^*)\rightarrow\mathcal{N}(\hat{\theta}|\theta^*, (N\mathrm{F}(\theta^*))^{-1})p(œÄ(D^)=Œ∏^‚à£D^‚àºŒ∏‚àó)‚ÜíN(Œ∏^‚à£Œ∏‚àó,(NF(Œ∏‚àó))‚àí1)
F\mathrm{F}FÔªø is the Fisher information matrix (FIM). It measures the amount of curvature of the log-likelihood at its peak.
Fij=Ex‚àºŒ∏[(‚àÇ‚àÇŒ∏ilog‚Å°p(x‚à£Œ∏))(‚àÇ‚àÇŒ∏jlog‚Å°p(x‚à£Œ∏))‚ä§]\mathrm{F}_{ij}=\mathbb{E}_{x\sim\theta}\Big[\Big(\frac{\partial}{\partial \theta_i} \log p(x|\theta)\Big)(\frac{\partial}{\partial \theta_j}\log p(x|\theta)\Big)^\top\Big]Fij‚Äã=Ex‚àºŒ∏‚Äã[(‚àÇŒ∏i‚Äã‚àÇ‚Äãlogp(x‚à£Œ∏))(‚àÇŒ∏j‚Äã‚àÇ‚Äãlogp(x‚à£Œ∏))‚ä§]
One can show that the FIM is also the Hessian of the NLL:
Fij=‚àíEx‚àºŒ∏[‚àÇ2‚àÇŒ∏iŒ∏jlog‚Å°p(x‚à£Œ∏)]\mathrm{F}_{ij}=-\mathbb{E}_{x\sim\theta}\Big[\frac{\partial^2}{\partial \theta_i \theta_j}\log p(x|\theta)\Big]Fij‚Äã=‚àíEx‚àºŒ∏‚Äã[‚àÇŒ∏i‚ÄãŒ∏j‚Äã‚àÇ2‚Äãlogp(x‚à£Œ∏)]
A log-likelihood function with high curvature (a large Hessian) will result in a low variance estimate since the parameters are well determined by the data.
4.7.3 Bootstrap approximation of the sampling distribution of any estimator
When the estimator is a complex function of the data (not jus the MLE) or when the sample size is small, we can approximate the sampling distribution using a Monte Carlo technique called the bootstrap.
The parametric bootstrap
Compute Œ∏^=œÄ(D)\hat{\theta}= \pi(\mathcal{D})Œ∏^=œÄ(D)Ôªø
Use it as plugin to create SSSÔªø datasets of size NNNÔªø:
D~(s)={xn‚àºp(xn‚à£Œ∏^):i=1:N}\tilde{\mathcal{D}}^{(s)}=\{x_n\sim p(x_n|\hat{\theta}):i=1:N\}D~(s)={xn‚Äã‚àºp(xn‚Äã‚à£Œ∏^):i=1:N}Ôªø
Compute our estimator for each sample, Œ∏^s=œÄ(D^(s))\hat{\theta}^{s}=\pi(\hat{\mathcal{D}}^{(s)})Œ∏^s=œÄ(D^(s))Ôªø. This empirical distribution is our estimate of the sampling distribution
The non-parametric bootstrap
Sample NNNÔªø points from D\mathcal{D}DÔªø with replacement, this create D(s)\mathcal{D}^{(s)}D(s)Ôªø
Compute our estimator as for each sample and draw the empirical distribution.
Note that on average, a sample only has 63.2% of unique data point, since the probability that an item is picked at least once is (1‚àí(1‚àí1/N)N)(1-(1-1/N)^N)(1‚àí(1‚àí1/N)N)Ôªø, which converges to 1‚àíe‚àí1=0.6321-e^{-1}=0.6321‚àíe‚àí1=0.632Ôªø
The bootstrap is a ‚Äúpoor man‚Äôs‚Äù posterior. In the common case where the estimator is a MLE and the prior is uniform, they are similar.
4.7.4 Confidence intervals
We use the variability induced by the sampling distribution to estimate the uncertainty of an a parameter estimate. We define a 100(1‚àíŒ±)%100(1-\alpha)\%100(1‚àíŒ±)%Ôªø-confidence interval as:
Pr‚Å°(Œ∏‚ààI(D~)‚à£D~‚àºŒ∏)=1‚àíŒ±\Pr(\theta\in I(\mathcal{\tilde{D}})|\mathcal{\tilde{D}}\sim \theta)=1-\alphaPr(Œ∏‚ààI(D~)‚à£D~‚àºŒ∏)=1‚àíŒ±
where the hypothetical data D~\tilde{\mathcal{D}}D~Ôªø is used to derives the interval I(D~)=(‚Ñì(D~),u(D~))I(\mathcal{\tilde{D}})=(\ell(\mathcal{\tilde{D}}), u(\mathcal{\tilde{D}}))I(D~)=(‚Ñì(D~),u(D~))Ôªø.
If Œ±=0.05\alpha=0.05Œ±=0.05Ôªø, this means that if we repeatedly sample data and compute I(D~)I(\mathcal{\tilde{D}})I(D~)Ôªø, 95% of such intervals would contains the parameter Œ∏.\theta.Œ∏.Ôªø
Suppose Œ∏‚àó\theta^* Œ∏‚àóÔªø is the unknown true parameter but we know Œî=Œ∏^‚àíŒ∏‚àó\Delta=\hat{\theta}-\theta^*Œî=Œ∏^‚àíŒ∏‚àóÔªø:
Pr‚Å°(Œ¥Œ±/2‚â§Œ∏^‚àíŒ∏‚àó‚â§Œ¥1‚àíŒ±/2)=1‚àíŒ±\Pr(\delta_{\alpha/2} \leq \hat{\theta}-\theta^*\leq \delta_{1-\alpha/2})=1-\alphaPr(Œ¥Œ±/2‚Äã‚â§Œ∏^‚àíŒ∏‚àó‚â§Œ¥1‚àíŒ±/2‚Äã)=1‚àíŒ±
By rearranging, we find (Œ∏^‚àíŒ¥1‚àíŒ±/2,Œ∏^‚àíŒ¥Œ±/2)(\hat{\theta}-\delta_{1-\alpha/2}, \hat{\theta}-\delta_{\alpha/2})(Œ∏^‚àíŒ¥1‚àíŒ±/2‚Äã,Œ∏^‚àíŒ¥Œ±/2‚Äã)Ôªø is a 100(1‚àíŒ±)%100(1-\alpha)\% 100(1‚àíŒ±)%Ôªø CI.
In most cases, we assume a Gaussian approximation to the sampling distribution:
NF(Œ∏^)(Œ∏^‚àíŒ∏‚àó)‚àºN(0,1)\sqrt{N \mathrm{F}(\hat{\theta})}(\hat{\theta}-\theta^*) \sim N(0, 1)NF(Œ∏^)‚Äã(Œ∏^‚àíŒ∏‚àó)‚àºN(0,1)
and thus we can compute and approximate CI using:
Œ∏^¬±zŒ±/2se^\hat{\theta} ¬± z_{\alpha/2}\hat{se}Œ∏^¬±zŒ±/2‚Äãse^
where zŒ±/2z_{\alpha/2}zŒ±/2‚ÄãÔªø is the Œ±/2\alpha/2Œ±/2Ôªø quantile of the Gaussian CDF and se^=1/NF(Œ∏^)\hat{se}=\sqrt{1/N\mathrm{F}(\hat{\theta}})se^=1/NF(Œ∏^‚Äã)Ôªø is the estimate standard error.
If the Gaussian approximation is not satisfactory, we can bootstrap the empirical distribution Œ∏^(D)‚àíŒ∏^(D(s))\hat{\theta}(\mathcal{D})-\hat{\theta}(\mathcal{D}^{(s)})Œ∏^(D)‚àíŒ∏^(D(s))Ôªø as an approximation to Œî\DeltaŒîÔªø.
4.7.5 Confidence intervals are not credible
A frequentist 95% CI is defined as an interval such that Pr‚Å°(Œ∏‚ààI(D~)‚à£D~‚àºŒ∏)=0.95\Pr(\theta \in I(\mathcal{\tilde{D}})|\mathcal{\tilde{D}}\sim\theta)=0.95Pr(Œ∏‚ààI(D~)‚à£D~‚àºŒ∏)=0.95Ôªø.
If I repeat the experiment over and over, then 95% of the time the CI contains the true mean.
It doesn‚Äôt mean that the parameter is 95% likely to live in the interval given by the observed data.
That quantity is instead given by the credible interval p(Œ∏‚ààI‚à£D)p(\theta \in I|\mathcal{D})p(Œ∏‚ààI‚à£D)Ôªø
These concepts are different: in the frequentist view, Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø is treated as a unknown, fixed constant, and the data as random. In the Bayesian view, the data is fixed (as it is known) and Œ∏\thetaŒ∏Ôªø is random.
4.7.6 The bias-variance tradeoff
In frequentist, data is a random variable drawn from some true but unknown distribution p‚àó(D)p^*(\mathcal{D})p‚àó(D)Ôªø. So the estimator has a sampling distribution p‚àó(Œ∏^(D))p^*(\hat{\theta}(\mathcal{D}))p‚àó(Œ∏^(D))Ôªø
The bias is defined as:
bias(Œ∏^(.))‚âúE[Œ∏^(D)]‚àíŒ∏‚àó\mathrm{bias}(\hat{\theta}(.))\triangleq\mathbb{E}[\hat{\theta}(\mathcal{D})]-\theta^*bias(Œ∏^(.))‚âúE[Œ∏^(D)]‚àíŒ∏‚àó
The MLE of the Gaussian mean is unbiased E[xÀâ]=Œº\mathbb{E}[\bar{x}]=\muE[xÀâ]=ŒºÔªø, but if Œº\muŒºÔªø is not known, the MLE of the Gaussian variance is biased:
E[œÉmle2]=E[1N‚àëi=1N(xi‚àíxÀâ)2]=N‚àí1NœÉ2\mathbb{E}[\sigma_{mle}^2]=\mathbb{E}[\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N(x_i-\bar{x})^2]=\frac{N-1}{N}\sigma^2E[œÉmle2‚Äã]=E[N1‚Äãi=1‚àëN‚Äã(xi‚Äã‚àíxÀâ)2]=NN‚àí1‚ÄãœÉ2
Intuitively, this is because we use up one point to get the mean. The unbiased estimator for the Gaussian variance is:

The bias variance tradeoff is given by:

It can be wise to use a biased estimator as long as it reduces the variance by more than the square of the bias.
MAP estimator for a Gaussian mean
Suppose we want to estimate the mean of a Gaussian from x=(x1,...,xn)x=(x_1,...,x_n)x=(x1‚Äã,...,xn‚Äã)Ôªø.
The MLE is unbiased and has a variance of V[xÀâ‚à£Œ∏‚àó]=œÉ2/N\mathbb{V}[\bar{x}|\theta^*]=\sigma^2/NV[xÀâ‚à£Œ∏‚àó]=œÉ2/NÔªø

x~‚âúNN+Œ∫0xÀâ+Œ∫0N+Œ∫0Œ∏0=wxÀâ+(1‚àíw)Œ∏0\tilde{x}\triangleq \frac{N}{N+\kappa_0}\bar{x}+\frac{\kappa_0}{N+\kappa_0}\theta_0=w\bar{x}+(1-w)\theta_0x~‚âúN+Œ∫0‚ÄãN‚ÄãxÀâ+N+Œ∫0‚ÄãŒ∫0‚Äã‚ÄãŒ∏0‚Äã=wxÀâ+(1‚àíw)Œ∏0‚Äã

MAP estimator for linear regression
MAP estimator for classification
If we use a 0-1 loss instead of the MSE, the frequentist risk is now Var√óbiasVar \times biasVar√óbiasÔªø. If the estimate is on the correct side of the classification, then the bias is negative, and decreasing the variance will decrease the misclassification rate.
However, if the estimate is wrong, the bias is positive and it pays to increase the variance. This illustrates that it is better to focus on the expected loss in classification, not on the bias and variance.
